data.contentText:
Cyanosis/bradycardia at birth should be assumed to be RESPIRATORY not cardiac

Cardiac lesions causing poor conditions at birth are rare (e.g. Ebstein's anomaly or arrythmia with hydrops)

Cardiac lesions can present when babies are hours/days old.

metadata.text1:
Monitor oxygen saturations. 

Consider treating for sepsis if requiring significant support

Use naso/orogastric feeds to decrease work of breathing

Organise an Echo and CXR

Monitor for signs of heart failure and consider diuretics
metadata.text2:
If left sided obstructive duct dependent heart disease suspected (e.g. hypoplastic left heart or aortic stenosis) 
- insert a UVC
- commence prostaglandin infusion at 10 nanograms/kg/min or PO 0.01-0.02 mg/kg/dose by NGT

- Aim for O2 saturations of >75%. Reduce inspired O2 if sats >85%
metadata.text3:
These include pulmonary atresia and critical pulmonary stenosis

Aim for sats >75%
- commence a prostaglandin as above
- if develops apnoeas or if sats <75% despite prostaglandin, ventilation should be initiated.
- if apnoeas but sats >75%, reduce prostaglandin, but not below 5 ng/kg/min.
